issue.title: Effect of setting sender.track to null

comment.body: @vivienlacourba Looks like the build system is broken again.

issue.title: Splitting transceiver direction into "direction" and "currentDirection".
issue.body:
"direction" is now purely what goes *into* SDP negotiation, and
"currentDirection" is purely what comes out of it.

Points to JSEP, depending on:
https://github.com/rtcweb-wg/jsep/pull/410

Related to issue #927.

comment.body: @taylor-b Did you base this PR on the latest build? Travis CI failed, possibly due to out-of-date dependencies.

issue.title: Effect of setting sender.track to null

comment.body: @pthatcherg @taylor-b New issue opened to allow replaceTrack to take a null: https://github.com/w3c/webrtc-pc/issues/947

issue.title: replaceTrack(null): Allowed?
issue.body: Currently, the argument to replaceTrack() cannot be null.  Since sender.track can be null in other methods (e.g. addTransceiver), why should it not be possible to replace an existing track with null (and cause the sender to stop sending)?

issue.title: Effect of setting sender.track to null

comment.body:
I think we should allow replaceTrack to take a null.  If it makes sense to
have an RtpSender without a track yet, it makes sense to be able to go from
having a track to not having a track.

On Tue, Nov 15, 2016 at 2:40 PM aboba <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> @taylor-b <https://github.com/taylor-b> Looking through the
> specification, some methods allow sender.track to be null and others do
> not. For example, addTransceiver can be called with a kind argument and
> no MediaStreamTrack, in which case transceiver.sender.track would be
> null. We have discussed whether PR #939
> <https://github.com/w3c/webrtc-pc/pull/939> for removeTrack should set
> sender.track to null. So it seems reasonable to review replaceTrack.
>

issue.title: Meta: auto-publish changes to the spec
issue.body:
Over and over again, I and others struggling with the fact that https://w3c.github.io/webrtc-pc/ does not reflect the latest changes, and is now almost two months out of date.

Examples of confusion:
* https://github.com/w3c/webrtc-pc/issues/816#issuecomment-251916135
* https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1316320#c3 (@jan-ivar)

Almost all specs these days auto-publish changes somewhere. There is rawgit.com/w3c/webrtc-pc/master/webrtc.html, but this is not the copy anyone links to and not one you'll find via search engines.

I understand there are some reasons for the current setup. If those are enumerated, perhaps a setup that doesn't have these downsides can be found?

comment.body: When I've linked the rawgit version in my code changes I've been told to link to the github.io version of specs instead because, I think, they're more stable/vetted, prone to contain less errors(?). Also the rawgit version has incorrect date for reference. But a lot of the times someone is implementing something fresh which hasn't reached github.io yet, so if you don't know this you're likely to get confused. If people clarify this in their changes they could tell reviewers to look at the rawgit version, but they might also be confused (took me a while before I realized there are multiple versions). I don't think everyone knows about the different spec versions, and the rawgit version is not listed at the top of the spec docs. When I'm reviewing code I usually start with the github.io version but if something seems off and I remember to I look at the rawgit too. I don't expect most people do this.

issue.title: Effect of setting sender.track to null

comment.body: @taylor-b Looking through the specification, some methods allow sender.track to be null and others do not.  For example,   `addTransceiver` can be called with a  `kind` argument and no MediaStreamTrack, in which case  `transceiver.sender.track` would be null.  We have discussed whether PR https://github.com/w3c/webrtc-pc/pull/939 for `removeTrack` should set  `sender.track` to null.  So it seems reasonable to review `replaceTrack`.

pull_request.title: Splitting transceiver direction into "direction" and "currentDirection".
pull_request.body:
"direction" is now purely what goes *into* SDP negotiation, and
"currentDirection" is purely what comes out of it.

Points to JSEP, depending on:
https://github.com/rtcweb-wg/jsep/pull/410

Related to issue #927.

issue.title: Section 6.2:  Issue 3 - buffered data at transport close
issue.body:
Section 6.2 contains the following note on Issue 3: 

ISSUE 3
The data transport protocol will specify what happens to, e.g. buffered data, when the data transport is closed.

comment.body:
Seen from the user, graceful close is much more useful (easier to reason about) than graceless close.
It does require notification that a graceless close has happened that can work after graceful close has been asked for. TCP has been able to live without API-visible confirmation that graceful close has completed (AFAIK) for many years, so that might not be a necessary function.

issue.title: Section 6.2:  Issue 3 - buffered data at transport close
issue.body:
Section 6.2 contains the following note on Issue 3: 

ISSUE 3
The data transport protocol will specify what happens to, e.g. buffered data, when the data transport is closed.

comment.body:
You don't even need signaling; you could set the `bufferedAmountLowThreshold` to 0 and wait for the `bufferedAmountLow` event to tell when the buffer is emptied.

It just seems odd to me that the default `close` is a half-graceful close. The data buffered at the WebRTC level will not be sent, but the data buffered at the SCTP level will. When would an application ever *want* this behavior (as opposed to fully graceful, or fully abrupt)?

issue.title: sender.setParameters():  Changing simulcast parameters?
issue.body:
Section 5.2 says: 

setParameters does not cause SDP renegotiation and can only be used to change what the media stack is sending or receiving within the envelope negotiated by Offer/Answer. The attributes in the RTCRtpParameters dictionary are designed to not enable this, so attributes like ssrc that cannot be changed are read only. 

[BA] This is reasonable as far as it goes.  However, parameters relevant to simulcast (e.g. maxFramerate, scaleResolutionDownBy, etc.) are listed as read/write and in addition, it is possible that setParameters() could be used to change things like the number of encodings to be sent. 

Could changes like that be judged to be "outside the envelope negotiated by Offer/Answer"?

issue.title: Section 6.2:  Issue 3 - buffered data at transport close
issue.body:
Section 6.2 contains the following note on Issue 3: 

ISSUE 3
The data transport protocol will specify what happens to, e.g. buffered data, when the data transport is closed.

comment.body:
Perhaps there's confusion here between datachannel.close(), and a failure or shutdown of the transport (connection failure, or (probably) peerconnection.close()).

In any case, Firefox currently implements a clear of buffered data on close() currently.  If you added a closeWithPromise(), that might be more "webby", though you probably want to be able to say "close now and drop any data" as well (spec close()).  The WebSockets API was designed before promises, of course.

To @feross  's point, the application can add a handshake after a transfer (or explicit I'm-going-to-close-please-ack message).  It can also ask about the amount of buffered data.

pull_request.title: Effect of setting sender.track to null

issue.title: Effect of sender.replaceTrack(null)
issue.body: The description of replaceTrack does not state that sender.replaceTrack(null) will cause the sender to stop sending.  This should be added.

issue.title: Section 6.2:  Issue 3 - buffered data at transport close
issue.body:
Section 6.2 contains the following note on Issue 3: 

ISSUE 3
The data transport protocol will specify what happens to, e.g. buffered data, when the data transport is closed.

comment.body: Yes, please support a way to send the buffered data before close. This is needed for our application, otherwise we can't be sure when to call `close()`

issue.title: STUN/TURN OAuth token auth parameter passing
issue.body:
I think there is a confusion between the current PeerConnection W3C API and RFC7635 
In STUN/TURN auth crendtials/parameters handover...

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7635#appendix-B

``` javascript
     HTTP/1.1 200 OK
        Content-Type: application/json
        Cache-Control: no-store

        {
          "access_token":
   "U2FsdGVkX18qJK/kkWmRcnfHglrVTJSpS6yU32kmHmOrfGyI3m1gQj1jRPsr0uBb
   HctuycAgsfRX7nJW2BdukGyKMXSiNGNnBzigkAofP6+Z3vkJ1Q5pWbfSRroOkWBn",
          "token_type":"pop",
          "expires_in":1800,
          "kid":"22BIjxU93h/IgwEb",
          "key":"v51N62OM65kyMvfTI08O"
          "alg":HMAC-SHA-256-128
        }
```

```
                        Figure 8: Response
```

Here below I have highlighted the three mandatory parameters that needed to pass to the ICE Agent
- "access_token":
- "kid":
- "key":

So we need to pass these 3 value at least to ICE Agent in the browser through PeerConnection iceServers configuration interface.

So according RFC 7635
- The key id (kid) (That is used like as username in Long Term Credential Auth),
  and has two other "credential" information pieces, that are needed to auth on remote TURN server. 
  -  the Session Key(Message Integrity, HMAC key). (That is used like as password in Long Term Credential Auth)
  -  the Access Token (SelfContaing token, e.g. Authenticated-Encryption with Associated-Data(AEAD) encrypted token.) In figure 8 it is the key:

See: https://w3c.github.io/webrtc-pc/#idl-def-rtciceserver

So in WebIDL I could find only one DOMString for Credential.

dictionary RTCIceServer {
    required (DOMString or sequence<DOMString>) urls;
             DOMString                          username;
             DOMString                          credential;
             RTCIceCredentialType               credentialType = "password";
};

And furthermore this credential field normally in case of "password" auth (Long Term Credential)  contains the Session Key(Message Integrity, HMAC key).

I am wondering what is the right way to pass the access token, the third value? 
How to pass the 3 information in 2 fields username/credential?
I propose to add a third field for the access_token, or add clarification in W3C PeerConnection.

The actual W3C webrtc-pc saying that the access_token need to be passed as credential
https://w3c.github.io/webrtc-pc/#rtcicecredentialtype-enum
"The credential is an access token"

Any comment highly appreciated!

comment.body:
I am ambivalent between option 2. and 1.

But prefer little bit more 
Option 2. 
- Do it right, this is the cleanest solution.
- I hope backward compatibility could be handled during transition in shims like adapter.js
  Most apps use adapter.js or similar shim already, so may it cause not big issue and could be handled.

Option 1.
- smallest change, 
- backward compatibility
- It gives back more how STUN message will use the oauth credentials. e.g. 
  - kid will be transported in username STUN attribute, 
  - and mac_key in credential will use as like password.

For me the hybrid (the Option 3.) is the least preferred option
- for me it is little bit confusing and I think for developer it will be not as clear as option 2. or option 1. 
- and because who knows may username will be not used in future auth schemes

issue.title: Section 6.2:  Issue 3 - buffered data at transport close
issue.body:
Section 6.2 contains the following note on Issue 3: 

ISSUE 3
The data transport protocol will specify what happens to, e.g. buffered data, when the data transport is closed.

comment.body:
@alvestrand In Chrome, we send all buffered data before starting the closing procedure. See: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/webrtc/issues/detail?id=4620

Could we maybe introduce two "close" methods, an abrupt close and a graceful close, to better accommodate the needs of different applications? We already have the concept of an abrupt close (which occurs when the buffer is filled to capacity), so this seems simple.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -4551,11 +4551,12 @@

Certificate Management

removeTrack
-

Stops sending media from sender. The - RTCRtpSender will still appear in - getSenders. Doing so will cause future calls to - createOffer to mark the media description for - the corresponding transceiver as recvonly or +

Stops sending media from sender, pending + negotiation. The RTCRtpSender
comment.body: I agree that `transceiver.stop`, `encodings[].active` and `setDirection` aren't solutions for this. But wouldn't disassociating the track from the sender work? If you call `addTransceiver`, you end up with a sender with a `null` track. So `removeTrack` could just return the sender to this state (of "can send, but have nothing to send"). Maybe this needs some list discussion. If we went this route it would also make sense to allow passing `null` into `replaceTrack`.

pull_request.title: Remove "stopped" from insertDTMF and replaceTrack
pull_request.body:
Depends on Taylor's "currentDirection" PR (do not merge)
Fix for Issue https://github.com/w3c/webrtc-pc/issues/917

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -4551,11 +4551,12 @@

Certificate Management

removeTrack
-

Stops sending media from sender. The - RTCRtpSender will still appear in - getSenders. Doing so will cause future calls to - createOffer to mark the media description for - the corresponding transceiver as recvonly or +

Stops sending media from sender, pending + negotiation. The RTCRtpSender
comment.body:
At the virtual interim, was there consensus about the "pending negotiation" part? It seems like it would be surprising if an application calls "removeTrack" but the track is still being sent, and `sender.track` never changes.

Should this method set `sender.track` to `null` (and immediately stop sending it), in addition to what you already have?

issue.title: Rules for negotiation-needed flag need to be updated for transceivers.
issue.body:
I found a few problems with the current rules regarding the negotiation-needed flag:
- It's still described overall in terms of tracks, not transceivers (such as in section 4.8.1).
- It's only cleared by `setLocalDescription`, but `setRemoteDescription` should be able to clear it as well in some cases.
- `createAnswer` sets the flag? I don't see the reasoning behind this. I'd expect setting a description to possibly set the flag, but not generating one.
- The act of firing `negotiationneeded` after reaching the stable signaling state also clears the flag? This means if the next SDP exchange didn't finish negotiating something (such as if it was initiated by the remote peer), the event wouldn't be fired again.

issue.title: Rules for negotiation-needed flag need to be updated for transceivers.
issue.body:
I found a few problems with the current rules regarding the negotiation-needed flag:
- It's still described overall in terms of tracks, not transceivers (such as in section 4.8.1).
- It's only cleared by `setLocalDescription`, but `setRemoteDescription` should be able to clear it as well in some cases.
- `createAnswer` sets the flag? I don't see the reasoning behind this. I'd expect setting a description to possibly set the flag, but not generating one.
- The act of firing `negotiationneeded` after reaching the stable signaling state also clears the flag? This means if the next SDP exchange didn't finish negotiating something (such as if it was initiated by the remote peer), the event wouldn't be fired again.

comment.body: Yes, the PR addressed all the problems I mentioned above.
